metadata.case_name: Appellant (Judgment Debtor) v. Respondents (Judgment Creditor and Auction Purchaser)

facts.text: Decree passed against the appellant (judgment debtor); judgment creditor took out execution proceedings.
Executing court ordered auction sale of the factory belonging to the appellant.

Amin (auction officer) held auction sale on September 10, 1962; Respondent No. 1 declared highest bidder for Rs. 2,45,000/-; 1/4th of sale proceeds (Rs. 61,250/-) required to be realized immediately after auction per O.21 R.84 CPC.
Appellant challenged auction sale alleging Amin did not realize 1/4th immediately; amount deposited in Treasury on September 11, 1962.
Appellant filed application under O.21 R.84 before Civil Judge, Aligarh.

Respondent No.1 contested: tendered amount immediately after auction; Amin hesitated due to large amount and late hour to deposit in Treasury; inquired if cheque acceptable, took Chhotelal (representative) to Munsif's residence; Munsif advised cash; accepted amount in car outside Munsif's house and issued receipt on September 10, 1962.

Civil Judge refused Respondent No.1's case; disbelieved Amin's report and evidence (no mention in report dated Sept 10, endorsement on Sept 11 seen as afterthought); noted Respondent No.1 withdrew Rs.1,51,000 from bank that day; set aside auction sale as nullity.

Respondent No.1 appealed to Allahabad High Court (Execution First Appeal No. 410 of 1962); High Court accepted Amin's report and evidence, found no contradiction with Munsif's evidence, no valid reason to doubt receipt and availability of cash; held no breach of O.21 R.84; reversed Civil Judge, upheld sale.
Supreme Court appeal by special leave; declined to interfere with High Court's factual findings under Art.136.

legal_issues.text: Whether an order by an executing Court setting aside an auction sale as a nullity (for non-compliance with O.21 R.84 CPC) is an appealable order.
Whether such an order falls under O.21 R.90, S.47 CPC, or is interlocutory/non-final.

petitioner_arguments.text: Order of Civil Judge under O.21 R.84 is not final but interlocutory; does not conclude execution proceedings, only orders fresh auction; no appeal lies before High Court.
Sale contrary to O.21 R.84 is nullity; O.21 R.90 does not apply (no material irregularity).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: O.21 R.84, R.90 CPC; Manilal Mohanlal Shah v. Sardar Sayed Ahmed (1955 1 SCR 108)

petitioner_arguments.text: Such order not under S.47 CPC; not a decree under S.2(2); cited Mrs. Peliti v. Kanshi Gopal.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant's application not under O.21 R.84 but under R.90 as objection to material irregularity in conduct/publication of sale.
Objection relates to execution of decree, falls under S.47 CPC; appealable as decree.

court_reasoning.text: High Court rightly held no breach of O.21 R.84; factual findings justified, no interference under Art.136.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence clear: amount tendered immediately, accepted soon after consulting Munsif; no contradiction in witnesses.

court_reasoning.text: O.21 RR.84-85 mandatory; non-compliance means no sale, nullity; R.90 inapplicable (Manilal Mohanlal Shah).

S.47 CPC wide, liberally construed; covers questions re execution/discharge/satisfaction of decree; includes auction purchaser (Explanation 1956); order setting aside sale for non-deposit under R.85 falls under S.47.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cited Nandlal v. Siddiqan, Veerayya v. Tiruchirapalli District Board.

court_reasoning.text: Order under S.47 is decree per S.2(2) CPC; appealable under S.96; final as determines rights between judgment-debtor and auction-purchaser.
court_reasoning.key_observation: From auction-purchaser's view: rights accrue post-bid; setting aside ends matter finally between parties.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished/rejected appellant's citations (Mrs. Peliti outdated post-Explanation; others inapplicable).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Finality: ends dispute on sale validity between JD and purchaser, though execution continues.

holdings.text: Order setting aside auction sale as nullity for non-compliance with O.21 R.84 falls under S.47 CPC; is a decree under S.2(2); appealable under S.96.
Such order finally determines rights/liabilities of judgment-debtor and auction-purchaser re the sale.

precedents_cited.case_name: Manilal Mohanlal Shah Ors. v. Sardar Sayed Ahmed Saiyed Mohammed Anr.
precedents_cited.relevance: RR.84-85 mandatory; non-compliance = no sale, nullity; R.90 inapplicable.
Order setting aside sale for non-payment under R.85 falls under S.47.
Application for review of re-sale order for R.85 non-compliance under S.47, appealable.
Held non-appealable; first ground outdated (Explanation to S.47); second ground rejected.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bharat National Bank v. Bhagwan Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Order on objections not final if re-sale ordered (from JD view).

precedents_cited.case_name: Jethanand Sons v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Final order: final decision on rights in dispute.

precedents_cited.case_name: Abdul Rahman v. D. K. Cassim

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs deposit post-auction (mandatory), setting aside sales, execution questions (deemed decree, appealable).

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Special leave appeal; discretion not to interfere in facts.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court's reversal of Civil Judge's order; confirmed no breach of O.21 R.84, sale valid; held order setting aside sale appealable under S.47/S.2(2)/S.96; dismissed appeal.

key_quotes.text: "This appeal by special leave raises the question whether an order by an executing Court setting aside an auction sale as a nullity is an appealable order."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Rules 84 and 85 of Order XXI being mandatory if they are not complied with there would be no sale at all and the Court is bound to order a resale."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "An order is final if it amounts to a final decision relating to the rights of the parties in dispute in the civil proceeding."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The order setting aside the auction sale amounts to a final decision relating to the rights of the parties in dispute... as between him and the judgment debtor."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holding on appealability from auction-purchaser's perspective.
